{{Italic title}} '''''{{lang|la|Bellum omnium contra omnes}}''''', a [[Latin language|Latin]] phrase meaning "the war of all against all", is the description that [[Thomas Hobbes]] gives to human existence in the [[state of nature]] [[thought experiment]] that he conducts in ''[[De Cive]]'' (1642) and ''[[Leviathan (book)|Leviathan]]'' (1651). The common modern English usage is a war of "each against all" where war is not commonly present.{{cite web |url=http://www.bartleby.com/71/0425.html|title=Each Against All|author=[[Charles Fourier]]|editor=[[Upton Sinclair]]| date=1st ed. 1915 |publisher: ''bartleby.com''|work=[http://www.amazon.com/Cry-Justice-Anthology-Protest-Literature/dp/1569800693 Cry for Justice: Anthology of Great Social Protest Literature] |publisher=Barricade Books|location=Fort Lee, New Jersey|pages=704|accessdate=13 August 2012}} ISBN 1-569-80069-3; ISBN 978-1-56980-069-0. ==Hobbes' use== In ''[[Leviathan_(book)|Leviathan]]'' itself,{{cite book|title=Leviathan |author=Thomas Hobbes |editor-first = Hermann |editor-last =Klenner |url=http://books.google.it/books?id=KJJ1HkxT_hoC&hl=en |pages=673|publisher=Meiner Verlag |year=2005}} [http://books.google.it/books?id=KJJ1HkxT_hoC&hl=en&pg=PA610&dq=%22a+warre,+as+is+of+every+man,+against+every+man%22+%22a+perpetuall+warre+of+every+man+against+his+neighbour%22+%22bellum+omnium+in+omnes%22+%22bellum+omnium+contra+omnes%22&hl=en&sa=X&ei=5GI3T47qFsXMtAb32rSZDA&ved=0CDIQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=%22a%20warre%2C%20as%20is%20of%20every%20man%2C%20against%20every%20man%22%20%22a%20perpetuall%20warre%20of%20every%20man%20against%20his%20neighbour%22%20%22bellum%20omnium%20in%20omnes%22%20%22bellum%20omnium%20contra%20omnes%22&f=false P. 610]. ISBN 3-787-31699-X; ISBN 978-3-78731-699-1. Hobbes speaks of 'warre of every one against every one',[http://books.google.it/books?id=BPtdfEZ2iDcC&pg=PA72&dq=%22Warre+of+every+one+against+every+one%22&hl=en#v=onepage&q=%22Warre%20of%20every%20one%20against%20every%20one%22&f=false Chapter 14]. of 'a war [...] of every man against every man'[http://books.google.it/books?id=BPtdfEZ2iDcC&hl=en&q=%22of%20every%20man%20against%20every%20man%22&f=false#v=snippet&q=%22of%20every%20man%20against%20every%20man%22&f=false Chapters 13-14]. and of 'a perpetuall warre of every man against his neighbour',[http://books.google.it/books?id=BPtdfEZ2iDcC&hl=en&q=%22a%20perpetuall%20warre%20of%20every%20man%20against%20his%20neighbour%22#v=snippet&q=%22a%20perpetuall%20warre%20of%20every%20man%20against%20his%20neighbour%22&f=false Chapter 24]. but the Latin phrase occurs in ''[[De Cive]]'': {{Quote|''Ostendo primo conditionem hominum extra societatem civilem (quam conditionem appellare liceat statum naturae) aliam non esse quam bellum omnium contra omnes; atque in eo bello jus esse omnibus in omnia''.[http://www.books.google.it/books?id=PeoTAAAAQAAJ&hl=en&pg=PP28&dq=%22of-+tendo+prima,+conditionemhomimtm+extra+focietatem+civilem+%5bquam+conditionem+appellare+liceat+fiatum+natura)+aliam+non+tffe+quam+bellum+omnium+contra+omnes%22 ''Praefatio'' ("Preface")].
I demonstrate in the first place, that the state of men without civil society (which state we may properly call the state of nature) war all men have equal right unto all things[http://www.google.it/search?num=100&hl=en&safe=off&tbm=bks&q=%22I+demonstrate%2C+in+the+first+place%2C+that+the+state+of+men+without+civil+society%2C+which+state+we+may+properly+call+the+state+of+nature%2C+is+nothing+else+but+a+mere+war+of+all+against+all%3B+and+in+that+war+all+men+have+equal+right+unto+all+things.%22 English translation] on Google Books.}} Later on, two slightly modified versions are presented in ''Libertas'' (liberty): {{Quote|''[...] Status hominum naturalis antequam in societatem coiretur, Bellum fuerit; neque hoc simpliciter, sed bellum omnium in omnes.''[http://www.books.google.it/books?id=PeoTAAAAQAAJ&hl=en&pg=PA15&dq=%22flatus+hominum+'+naturalis+antequam+in+focietatem+coire-+tur,+Bellum+fuerit+;+nequehocfimplici-+ter,fed+bellum+omnium+in+omnes.%22 Chapter 1, section 12].
The natural state of men, before they entered into society, was a mere war, and that not simply, but a war of all men against all men.[http://www.google.it/search?num=100&hl=en&safe=off&tbo=1&tbm=bks&q=%22De+Cive%22+%22The+natural+state+of+men%2C+before+they+entered+into+society%2C+was+a+mere+war%2C+and+that+not+simply%2C+but+a+war+of+all+men+against+all+men.%22 English translation] on Google Books.}} {{Quote|''Nam unusquisque naturali necessitate bonum sibi appetit, neque est quisquam qui bellum istud omnium contra omnes, quod tali statui naturaliter adhæret, sibi existimat esse bonum''.[http://www.books.google.it/books?id=PeoTAAAAQAAJ&hl=en&pg=PA16&dq=%22Nam+unus-+quifque+naturali+neceflitate+bonum+íibú+appétit+,+ñeque+eft+quisquam+qui+bellum+iftud+omnium+contra+omnes,+quod+tali+ftatui+naturaliteradhxret+,+fibi+exiftimat+cffe+bonum.%22 Chapter 1, section 13].
For every man by natural necessity desires that which is good for him: nor is there any that esteems a war of all against all, which necessarily adheres to such a state, to be good for him.[http://www.google.it/search?num=100&hl=en&safe=off&tbm=bks&q=%22De+Cive%22+%22For+every+man+by+natural+necessity+desires+that+which+is+good+for+him%3A+nor+is+there+any+that+esteems+a+war+of+all+against+all%2C+which+necessarily+adheres+to+such+a+state%2C+to+be+good+for+him.%22 English translation] on Google Books.}} In chapter XIII of ''Leviathan'',{{cite web |url=http://www.bartleby.com/34/5/13.html |title=Chapter XIII - Of the Natural Condition of Mankind as Concerning Their Felicity and Misery |author=Thomas Hobbes |date= |work= |publisher=''bartleby.com'' |accessdate=15 August 2012}} Hobbes explains the concept with these words: {{Quote|Hereby it is manifest that during the time men live without a common power to keep them all in awe, they are in that condition which is called war; and such a war as is of every man against every man.{{cite book |title=Leviathan |author=Thomas Hobbes |year=1976 |publisher=Forgotten Books |location=Charleston, South Carolina |pages=409 |url=http://books.google.it/books?id=-Q4nPYeps6MC&hl=en}} [http://books.google.it/books?id=-Q4nPYeps6MC&pg=PA86&hl=en&dq=%22Hereby+it+is+manifest+that+during+the+time+men+live+without+a+common+power+to+keep+them+all+in+awe,+they+are+in+that+condition+which+is+called+war;+and+such+a+war+as+is+of+every+man+against+every+man.%22#v=onepage&q=%22Hereby%20it%20is%20manifest%20that%20during%20the%20time%20men%20live%20without%20a%20common%20power%20to%20keep%20them%20all%20in%20awe%2C%20they%20are%20in%20that%20condition%20which%20is%20called%20war%3B%20and%20such%20a%20war%20as%20is%20of%20every%20man%20against%20every%20man.%22&f=false P. 86]. ISBN 1-605-06977-9; ISBN 978-1-60506-977-7. [...] In such condition there is no place for industry, because the fruit thereof is uncertain: and consequently no culture of the earth; no navigation, nor use of the commodities that may be imported by sea; no commodious building; no instruments of moving and removing such things as require much force; no knowledge of the face of the earth; no account of time; no arts; no letters; no society; and which is worst of all, continual fear, and danger of violent death; and the life of man solitary, poor, nasty, brutish, and short.[http://books.google.it/books?id=-Q4nPYeps6MC&pg=PA86&hl=en&dq=%22In+such+condition+there+is+no+place+for+industry,+because+the+fruit+thereof+is+uncertain:+and+consequently+no+culture+of+the+earth;+no+navigation,+nor+use+of+the+commodities+that+may+be+imported+by+sea;+no+commodious+building;+no+instruments+of+moving+and+removing+such+things+as+require+much+force;+no+knowledge+of+the+face+of+the+earth;+no+account+of+time;+no+arts;+no+letters;+no+society;+and+which+is+worst+of+all,+continual+fear,+and+danger+of+violent+death;+and+the+life+of+man+solitary,+poor,+nasty,+brutish,+and+short.%22#v=onepage&q=%22In%20such%20condition%20there%20is%20no%20place%20for%20industry%2C%20because%20the%20fruit%20thereof%20is%20uncertain%3A%20and%20consequently%20no%20culture%20of%20the%20earth%3B%20no%20navigation%2C%20nor%20use%20of%20the%20commodities%20that%20may%20be%20imported%20by%20sea%3B%20no%20commodious%20building%3B%20no%20instruments%20of%20moving%20and%20removing%20such%20things%20as%20require%20much%20force%3B%20no%20knowledge%20of%20the%20face%20of%20the%20earth%3B%20no%20account%20of%20time%3B%20no%20arts%3B%20no%20letters%3B%20no%20society%3B%20and%20which%20is%20worst%20of%20all%2C%20continual%20fear%2C%20and%20danger%20of%20violent%20death%3B%20and%20the%20life%20of%20man%20solitary%2C%20poor%2C%20nasty%2C%20brutish%2C%20and%20short.%22&f=false ''Ibid.'']}} The thought experiment places people in a pre-social condition, and theorizes what would happen in such a condition. According to Hobbes, the outcome is that people choose to enter a [[social contract]], giving up some of their liberties in order to enjoy peace. This thought experiment is a test for the [[Legitimacy (political)|legitimation]] of a [[Sovereign state|state]] in fulfilling its role as "[[sovereignty|sovereign]]" to guarantee social order, and for comparing different types of states on that basis. Hobbes distinguishes between war and battle: war does not only consist of actual battle; it points to the situation in which one knows there is a 'will to contend by battle'.[http://books.google.it/books?id=-Q4nPYeps6MC&pg=PA86&hl=en&dq=%22the+will+to+contend+by+battle%22#v=onepage&q=%22the%20will%20to%20contend%20by%20battle%22&f=false ''Ibid.''] ==Later uses== Sometimes the phrase is used by [[Karl Marx|Marx]] and [[Friedrich Engels|Engels]]. * In ''[[On the Jewish Question]]'' (1843-4): {{Quote|Religion has become the spirit of ''[[civil society]]'', of the sphere of egoism, of ''bellum omnium contra omnes''.{{cite web |url=http://webcache.googleusercontent.com/search?q=cache:uzuV6LQ19cMJ:www.marxists.org/archive/marx/works/1844/jewish-question/+%22Karl+Marx%22+%22On+the+Jewish+Question%22+%22Religion+has+become+the+spirit+of+civil+society,+of+the+sphere+of+egoism,+of+bellum+omnium+contra+omnes.%22&cd=1&hl=en&ct=clnk&gl=en |title=On The Jewish Question - Works of Karl Marx 1844 |author=marxists.org/archive/marx/works |date= |work= |publisher= |accessdate=13 February 2012}}}} * In ''[[Grundrisse|Outlines of the Critique of Political Economy]]'' (1857-1858): {{quote|One could just as well deduce from this abstract phrase that each individual reciprocally blocks the assertion of the others' interests, so that, instead of a general affirmation this war of all against all produces a general negation.{{cite web |url=http://webcache.googleusercontent.com/search?q=cache:BD6QNQzsh7QJ:www.marxists.org/archive/marx/works/1857/grundrisse/ch03.htm+%22One+could+just+as+well+deduce+from+this+abstract+phrase+that+each+individual+reciprocally+blocks+the+assertion+of+the+others%E2%80%99+interests,+so+that,+instead+of+a+general+affirmation+this+war+of+all+against+all+produces+a+general+negation%22&cd=2&hl=en&ct=clnk&gl=en|title=The Grundrisse NOTEBOOK I October 1857 The Chapter on Money (Part II)|author=|date= |work= |publisher=marxists.org/archive/marx/works/1857/grundrisse/ch03.htm#p156 |accessdate=4 March 2012}}}} :The English translation eliminates the Latin phrase used in the original German.{{cite web |url=http://webcache.googleusercontent.com/search?q=cache:q3LyrqwP060J:emanzipationoderbarbarei.blogsport.de/studium/dokumente/karl-marx-grundrisse-der-kritik-der-politischen-akonomie/entstehung-und-wesen-des-geldes/+%22Vielmehr+k%C3%B6nnte+aus+dieser+abstrakten+Phrase+gefolgert+werden,+da%C3%9F+jeder+wechselseitig+die+Geltendmachung+des+Interesses+der+andern+hemmt,+und+statt+einer+allgemeinen+Affirmation,+vielmehr+eine+allgemeine+Negation+aus+diesem+bellum+omnium+contra+omnes+resultiert.%22&cd=5&hl=en&ct=clnk&gl=en|title=Entstehung und Wesen des Geldes. Grundrisse der Kritik der politischen Ökonomie|author=|date= |work= |publisher=emanzipationoderbarbarei.blogsport.de/studium/dokumente/karl-marx-grundrisse-der-kritik-der-politischen-akonomie/entstehung-und-wesen-des-geldes/|accessdate=4 March 2012}} * In a letter from Marx to Engels (18 June 1862): {{quote|It is remarkable how [[Charles Darwin|Darwin]] rediscovers, among the beasts and plants, the society of England with its division of labour, competition, opening up of new markets, 'inventions' and [[Thomas Robert Malthus|Malthusian]] 'struggle for existence'. It is Hobbes' ''bellum omnium contra omnes''.{{cite web |url=http://webcache.googleusercontent.com/search?q=cache:XV123szvUikJ:www.marxists.org/archive/marx/works/1862/letters/62_06_18.htm+%22the+beasts+and+plants,+the+society+of+England+with+its+division+of+labour,+competition,+opening+up+of+new+markets,%22+inventions+%22and+Malthusian%22+%22struggle+for+existence%22+%22It+is+Hobbes%E2%80%99%22+%22bellum+omnium+contra+omnes%22&cd=1&hl=en&ct=clnk&gl=en |title=Marx-Engels Correspondence 1862|author=|date= |work= |publisher=marxists.org/archive/marx/works/1862/letters/62_06_18.htm |accessdate=4 March 2012}}}} It was also used by [[Friedrich Nietzsche]] in ''[[On Truth and Lies in a Nonmoral Sense]]'' (1873): {{Quote|Insofar as the individual wants to preserve himself against other individuals, in a natural state of affairs he employs the intellect mostly for simulation alone. But because man, out of need and boredom, wants to exist socially, herd-fashion, he requires a peace pact and he endeavors to banish at least the very crudest ''bellum omnium contra omnes'' from his world.[[Walter Kaufmann (philosopher)|Walter Kaufmann]]'s translation in {{cite book|title=The portable Nietzsche |url=http://books.google.it/books?id=wY0gAQAAMAAJ&hl=en |pages=692 |publisher=Chatto & Windus|year=1971}} [http://books.google.it/books?id=wY0gAQAAMAAJ&q=%22socially,+herd-fashion,+he+requires+a+peace+pact+and+he+endeavors+to+banish+at+least+the+very+crudest+bellum+omnium+contra+omnes1+from+his+world%22&dq=%22socially,+herd-fashion,+he+requires+a+peace+pact+and+he+endeavors+to+banish+at+least+the+very+crudest+bellum+omnium+contra+omnes1+from+his+world%22&hl=en&sa=X&ei=Z0M4T5bbF46h-Qb_hNX1AQ&ved=0CDIQ6AEwAA P. 44].
